Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Factors Influencing Cooperation and Adversity in Water Infrastructure Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This research examines what forces contribute to cooperation or adversity in contexts of resource scarcity and population displacement. While population displacement is often characterized as contributing to tension in the host contexts to where these populations are displaced, less understood are the conditions that promote cooperation and solidarity, especially in circumstances of protracted displacement and shared residence. This dissertation research addresses these questions by investigating the role of communal water infrastructure, such as public water taps, water truck deliveries, and wells, in promoting cooperation, or instigating tension, between residents of various social, religious, and economic backgrounds. In addition to supporting the training of a doctoral student, the findings from this project will be shared with organizations, development practitioners, and policy experts.<br/><br/>This doctoral dissertation project examines the factors influencing access to water and the maintenance of communal water infrastructure. This project compares two localities: one marked by citizen-displaced population cooperation and solidarity, and another by continued tension. Both localities contain similar communal water infrastructures which serve as routine gathering sites for both citizen and refugee residents. This project therefore investigates how a shared dependence on infrastructure can enable cooperative relations. In addition to examining how residents' social worlds frame their encounters, this project explores how infrastructure breakdown, repair, and neglect reconfigure social relations. Ethnographic research methods are employed, including participant observation, interviews, and archival research among resident populations, as well as with non-governmental actors who oversee the infrastructure. This research contributes to contemporary social science and anthropology by better understanding the role of communal infrastructure in mediating and reconfiguring cooperative and conflictual social relations.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Based on twelve months of ethnographic fieldwork, this project explored the social life of water in Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley, a region with significant refugee and citizen co-residence. “Social life” refers to the political, technical, affective, and fundamentally human qualities that water possesses. This is a deliberately capacious framing to analyze the movements of an inherently boundless and porous substance. The research considers a range of forms that water flows assumed, from the contentious concerns of natural water springs to the governmental efforts of domesticating water for household use; the humanitarian concerns of provisioning water to refugee communities living off-grid to environmental anxieties of wastewater leakage. As water takes different shape, it absorbs varying social and political concerns, and reveals the intersections and contestations of citizen and refugee life.

This project speaks to influential literatures on infrastructure, human and more-than-human ecologies, and migration and refugee studies. More than simply the material underbelly of modern life, infrastructure is a terrain of political negotiation and contestation among citizens and refugees living in shared residence. Expanding a focus on static infrastructures such as pipes, this project centrally examines water trucks as mobile infrastructures, and the temporary infrastructures of water and septic tanks for off-grid residents. This project also speaks to ecological and environmental literatures in the social sciences. As water becomes an increasingly scarce and polluting resource in Lebanon, my project speaks to ecology and concerns of (im)purity in light of anthropogenic climate crises.

Centrally, this project will produce a dissertation and a number of academic articles, supporting the career of a PhD candidate. The research will also speak to the humanitarian and development sector, informing best practices for projects dealing with citizens and refugees living in close residence. By examining the social life of water, the project seeks to understand the relations, contradictions, and possibilities between the fundamental source of life, and the ways that residents attempt (or refuse) to make life with one another. While water is sometimes the source of tension among citizens and refugees in Lebanon, it is often a revelatory substance, washing away residue that obscures, absorbing sediments and sentiments along its path, and clarifying possible routes forward.
